item.title: Mafia: The Old Country Free Ride Update Adds Classic Difficulty, New Races, Combat Challenges, and More
item.content:encoded:
Mafia: The Old Country receives its biggest update since launch today. The 'Free Ride' update introduces many new features and content, including Classic difficulty (which requires careful management of both health and ammunition), new horse and car races, new replayable combat challenges, an optional first-person driving perspective, and a Photo Mode.

Those who'd like to enhance the cinematic flair of their experience in Mafia: The Old Country can now activate Cinema Siciliano, which transforms the game's look into a black-and-white masterpiece inspired by vintage Italian films. Lastly, the Free Ride update also introduces new vehicles, guns, knives, outfits, and charms for players to acquire.

Mafia: The Old Country launched in early August to solid reviews from critics. In my review, I rated it 8 out of 10 and called it a fine Sicilian Mafia story:

Mafia: The Old Country aims squarely at being a narrative experience, and largely succeeds in that while also providing solid gameplay. It is a bit of a shame that we don't get to explore Sicily in this game, but if you're into Mafia narratives, this is among the best you can find in games, and the price isn't so high to boot.

Publisher 2K later boasted of the game's sales, revealing that it has been outperforming expectations. A couple of months ago, one of the main actresses from the game, Carina Conti, let slip that she heard the publisher may have already greenlighted a new game. This remains unconfirmed for the time being, but the parent company has hinted that the new approach of a shorter, more linear cinematic game has been successful, thus suggesting that developer Hangar 13 will continue down this path in the future.

Of course, we'll keep you updated should there be any new leaks or rumors of a sequel.

Several Logitech headsets are discounted at Amazon for Black Friday, including the premium Logitech G Astro A50 X Wireless--which is available at Amazon with a $70 discount. You'll also find the Logitech G Astro A50 Wireless for $240 (was $300) and the Logitech G Astro A10 Gen 2 Wired Headset for $50 (was $70). Check out a full breakdown of the discounted headsets below, and be sure to browse GameSpot's Black Friday Deals Hub for price cuts on other PC gaming hardware, Blu-rays, books, and more.

Logitech G Astro A50 X Wireless Headset

$330 (was $400)

The Logitech G Astro A50 X is the most luxurious of the trio of products on sale for Black Friday. Available in black or white, it supports PS5, Xbox, and PC, and you can switch between them simultaneously at the press of a button. You can also use it with Nintendo Switch while the console is docked. The main attraction, however, is unique HDMI 2.1 Passthrough technology, offering 24-bit/48kHz audio that should impress even the most discerning audiophile.

Aside from its cool HDMI tech, the headset is equipped with everything else you'd expect from a $300+ gadget. This includes Pro-G Graphene audio drivers (40mm), the ability to listen to two devices at once, up to 24 hours of battery life, and a mobile app to help you optimize its performance. There's also an included docking station with LED lights that lets you quickly recharge your headset between play sessions.

Logitech G Astro A50 Wireless Headset

$240 (was $300)

This offers many of the same features as the A50 X, though it skips out on the HDMI Passthrough technology. Beyond that, you can still connect to PS5, Xbox, Switch, and PC, you'll still get Pro-G Graphene audio drivers (40mm), and you'll still get an included base station for charging. The same mobile app also lets you tweak a variety of settings like stream output mixing, mic settings, and other variables, and the overall design of the A50 is essentially the same as the A50 X.

Note that if you're playing on PC, this will support the same 24-bit/48kHz as the A50 X. On console, performance drops to 16-bit/48kHz. In short, if you're playing just on PC, this is the headset to get. If you're playing on console, you'll have to decide if the slight performance bump of the A50 X is worth an extra $90.

Logitech G Astro A10 Gen 2 Wired Headset

$50 ($70)

Just need a reliable headset that won't break the bank? Take a peek at the Logitech G Astro A10 Gen 2 now that it's just $50 (was $70). Its stat sheet won't blow you away, but priced at $50, it's a pretty good deal. The wired 3.5mm connection supports PS5, Xbox, Switch, and PC, a flip-to-mute microphone makes it easy to chat with teammates, and its 32mm drivers should be good enough for most casual players.

Logitech built the headset to be durable too, with a flexible headband that can take a beating and oversized earcups that should be comfy during long play sessions. Several different colors and patterns are on sale--making it easy to find something that fits your style.

item.title: Nippon Ichi Software announces Shinigami Hime to Ishokan no Kaibutsu for PS5, Switch 2, and Switch
item.content:encoded:
■ About

  • Title: Shinigami Hime to Ishokan no Kaibutsu
  • Genre: Fairy Tale-Destroying Adventure
  • Platforms: PlayStation 5 / Switch 2 / Switch
  • Release Date: April 30, 2026 (Japan)
  • Players: 1
  • Price:
    • PlayStation 5 / Switch 2: ¥8,200 (¥9,020 with tax)
    • Switch: ¥7,200 (¥7,920 with tax)
  • Publisher: Nippon Ichi Software
  • Director / Scenario: Kento Jobana
  • Character Design: Sayaka Oda
  • Main Theme: Akiko Shikata
  • Background Music: Takeshi Matsumoto (G-angle)
  • CERO: TBD (Pending Review)
  • Official Website: nippon1.jp
  • Official X: @usotsukihime
  • Official Hashtag: #シニガミ姫
  • Copyright: ©2026 Nippon Ichi Software, Inc.

Shinigami Hime to Ishokan no Kaibutsu is the latest entry in the “picture book” series by Nippon Ichi Software that explores the interactions between humans and monsters, following The Liar Princess and the Blind Prince and The Cruel King and the Great Hero. As with the previous titles, the character design and worldview are handled by Sayaka Oda, with Kento Jobana (known for his work on Disgaea 7: Vows of the Virtueless, Bar Stella Abyss, etc.) responsible for the scenario.

This game tells a story of heart-to-heart connections and salvation surrounding Mono, a girl who visits the medical facility “Ishokan” in hopes of saving her older sister, who has been afflicted by the terrifying “Shinigami Disease”; Melhendia, a goat-like creature who seeks to exploit her; and the girls who the disease have transformed into strange creatures.

The picture book-like expressions with analog illustrations that have defined the series return, while the deliberate use of monochrome fields sets it apart from previous titles, creating a world that is eerie and strange, yet still somehow beautiful.

Players will be able to interact with the world of the picture book, “destroying” or “transforming” it, offering a fresh and unique gameplay experience.

■ Story

The protagonist, a young girl named Mono, is a lonely girl who was abandoned by her parents despite being the descendant of famous opera singers. She lives quietly in the attic of the theater while being worked like a servant day after day.

Until recently, her beloved older sister would always visit her room and teach her opera and dance, but… now she has gone missing.

One day, Mono discovers the whereabouts of her sister.

Her sister is at “Ishokan,” an isolation facility for those afflicted by the “Shinigami Disease” epidemic.

Shinigami Disease is a terrifying illness that turns living beings into picture books, which then “emerge” into monsters, and the nation has given up on finding a cure.

“My sister is gonna turn into a monster… No way! I don’t want that!”

Unable to sit back and do nothing, Mono visits Ishokan.

In order to explore the monster-filled Ishokan and the “World of Trauma” that unfolds within the picture books the girls mutated into, Mono forms a contract with the legendary monster Mel.

“Please protect me, Mel.”

“Yahaha… I’ll protect you. Let’s get along well, human.”

Even knowing that Mel is plotting revenge against humans, Mono is determined to save the only family who has ever loved her…

■ Characters

Mono Brightman (voiced by Rena Motomura)
A Girl Trying to Save Her Sister

A lonely girl who lives in the attic of an opera theater. Treated coldly by her parents, who were famous opera singers, she handles odd jobs around the theater while living in a small attic room.

While she lacks self-confidence and has a timid personality, she hopes to become a kind person like her older sister, and when she sees someone injured, she cannot help but help them—even if they are monsters.

Melhendia (voiced by Makoto Koichi)
A Monster-Eating Monster

↓

Nickname: Mel. A legendary monster, infamous even among the creatures of Ishokan. Cursed with a collar for the crime of harming a human, he was confined to a room in Ishokan. He wields a power called “Papereater,” which allows him to grow stronger by consuming other monsters and those born of Shinigami Disease. To regain his former strength and free himself from the curse, he seeks Mono’s cooperation.

A sarcastic creature who despises humans, he constantly clashes with the good-natured Mono.

Birdler (voiced by Mayumi Shintani)
Mono’s Charming Servant

A bird monster who was saved by Mono and Mel after becoming increasingly grotesque and violent. He loves talking to humans, calls himself Mono’s “butler,” and supports her on her adventures with his vast knowledge.

Anciel Brightman (voiced by Reina Kondou)
A Talented “Future Grand Actress”

Mono’s older sister, who, unlike Mono, had been active as an opera singer from a young age and was regarded as having a promising future. She was the only family member who treated Mono kindly, remaining a steady source of emotional support for her. When her chronic illness worsened, she contracted Shinigami Disease and was taken to Ishokan.

■ A Game Set Inside a Picture Book: An Evolved “Playable Picture Book”

Shinigami Hime to Ishokan no Kaibutsu is an adventure game where you gather various items scattered throughout each stage.

The game is set in Ishokan, a facility for patients afflicted with Shinigami Disease, and the “worlds inside picture books” that are isolated in various places throughout Ishokan.

While searching for her older sister, who was turned into a picture book due to Shinigami Disease, Mono and her companions come across the picture books of various other girls. They then set off on an adventure through these picture-book worlds to uncover the cause of the girls’ transformations and return them to human form.

Inside each picture book lies an eerie monochrome world that embodies the trauma of each girl. Solve its various gimmicks to progress.

—Ishokan is a place where various monsters have settled, serving as the base for Mono and her companions.

—To save the girls suffering from trauma, Mono and her companions travel through the worlds of various picture books.

—As you progress through a picture book’s world, you will obtain “Memory Bookmarks” that record the girls’ traumas. By learning their stories and defeating the “Shinigami Princess” lurking at the end of each stage, you can save the girls who have become Shinigami Princesses.

—The stories of the girls who have been turned into picture books are told in a picture book style, accompanied by illustrations and narration by Sayaka Oda.

■ Interfering with the Worlds of Picture Books: Papereater

In this game, you can “interfere” with the monochrome worlds inside picture books.

Mono’s companion Mel can eat and “destroy” the monochrome worlds created by the Shinigami Disease.

Not only can he devour the paper monsters standing in your way, but also the rocks and trees blocking your path, dead ends, and even messages sent by monsters!? Anything depicted in monochrome can be eaten and destroyed.

—Chomp through the obstacles blocking your way! You can even carve out new paths by eating them!

—Even suspicious messages can be chomped away if they’re monochrome! Destroying them might just reveal a new route…!

—Only Mel can eat the picture book worlds. Instruct him as you proceed through each world.

Eat Too Much and Mel Will Go on a Rampage

Using Papereater causes changes in Mel. The more he eats, the more power he regains—and the more ferocious he becomes.

—If he eats too much, Mel will undergo a dramatic transformation.

—A giant Mel can chomp down even massive monsters with ease.

The stronger Mel’s power grows, the larger the area he can consume. However, if he becomes too ferocious, he’ll lose control and may become unable to move to other areas, putting Mono in danger.

You’ll need to decide carefully what Mel should eat so that he doesn’t go berserk.

—If Mel grows too big and too ferocious, he’ll start ignoring Mono’s instructions…!

■ Interfering with the Worlds of Picture Books: Turn Over

As you progress through your adventure, you will acquire various skills beyond eating and destroying. One of these is Mono’s skill “Turn Over,” which allows her to manipulate the colored parts of the world that Mel cannot eat.

—When you Turn Over a spot where the page is slightly lifted…

—Part of the background will flip open with a whap! revealing hidden passageways and items!

—You can even slip into the shadows behind a turned-over background to evade giant monsters.

By Turning Over parts of the world, you can uncover new paths hidden on the other side—or use the flipped background to hide from enemies. There are many ways to interact with picture-book worlds beyond simply “eating and destroying.”

■ At The End of Each Stage, You Will Fight a Completely Changed Girl…

As you progress deeper through each stage, gathering “Memory Bookmarks” that tell the girls’ story, you will encounter a girl transformed by her trauma into a “Shinigami Princess.” Defeat the Shinigami Princess and free the girl from her trauma.

■ The First Stage’s Shinigami Princess

Shepherdess Girl / Ookami Princess (voiced by Tsunomaki Watame)

A girl who has transformed into a giant, sheep-like monster known as the “Ookami Princess.”

Born as the eldest daughter of a shepherding family, she is a hardworking girl devoted to her family. Though poor, she worked diligently and lived a happy life.

Her flaw is that she pushes herself too hard.

One day, in the brief moment she took her eyes off her little sister, the girl disappeared…

“Koyou no Mori” is the world that embodies the shepherdess girl’s trauma.

Eerie, lifelike trees fill the dense forest, where man-eating wolves wander.

■ When You Save a Girl, The World Vibrantly Changes

When you defeat a Shinigami Princess, the girl overcomes her trauma, and her once-monochrome world blossoms with beautiful color. It is proof that her heart has been healed, and that she can finally move forward.

■ Box Art

—PlayStation 5

—Switch 2

—Switch

■ Nippon1.jp Shop Limited Edition

The Nippon1.jp Shop Limited Edition will cost 24,000 yen (26,400 yen with tax) for PlayStation 5 and Switch 2, and 23,000 yen (25,300 yen with tax) for Switch, and includes the following content:

  • A copy of the game
  • Mel plushie (size: W200mm x H200mm x D200mm)
  • Mel and Birdler plushie mascot set (total length: 10cm—including ball chain)
  • Illustrated card set
  • Wooden broach set (x3) (size: W40mm x H40mm x D5mm)
  • Art book (A5 size, 32 pages)
  • Soundtrack CD (23 tracks including background music and songs)

Pre-Order Bonus

Users who pre-order the game at retailers, electronic commerce sites, or Nippon1.jp Shop will receive a limited production wooden bookmark designed by Sayaka Oda. Pre-order by February 9, 2026 to make sure you get one.

You don't have to travel to a galaxy far (far!) away for a Star Wars adventure, as this Black Friday deal on Star Wars Outlaws will make you feel like a sci-fi freelancer pulling off the ultimate heist. Star Wars Outlaws recently launched for the Switch 2--exactly one year after it landed on PS5, Xbox, and PC--and you can get a big discount on it. Amazon's Black Friday deal shaves $20 off the cover price, dropping it down to just $40 (was $60) for the feature-packed game.

Star Wars Outlaws (Switch 2 Edition)

$40 (was $60)

Set during the height of the Galactic Empire's reign, Outlaws puts you in the boots of Kay Vess, an opportunistic lawbreaker chasing down a score that'll help pay off the debts she owes to the criminal underworld of Star Wars. The third-person action-adventure unfolds across several planets and outer space, mixing exploration, combat, stealth, and interstellar dogfights together in a way that feels like a polished Star Wars experience.

This version of the game also includes the two post-launch expansions--Wild Card and A Pirate's Fortune--as well as the Jabba's Gambit DLC mission, Hunter's Legacy bundle, and Cartel Ronin cosmetic packs. The Switch 2 version comes with all these changes already implemented, making it a great time right out of the box--albeit with some graphical concessions to ensure the game runs at a stable 30fps in either Docked or Handheld mode.

You can also pick the game up on PS5 and Xbox Series X. These versions don't include the two story expansions, but they do come with the Rogue Infiltrator Character Pack cosmetics for Kay and her cute partner-in-crime, Nix.

item.title: Hell is Us Is $10 Off In Amazon's Early Black Friday Sale
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

New-in-box copies of Hell is Us are discounted on Amazon as part of their Black Friday deals. You can get the PlayStation 5 or Xbox Series X versions for $40 (was $60). The semi-open world action RPG launched just a few weeks in September, so this discounted price is a good time to jump in if you've been curious about the game.

Hell is Us

$40 (was $60)

The standard physical edition of Hell Is Us comes in a standard box and includes the full game on your platform of choice. There is no extra content like the Deluxe Edition. It's not a short adventure by any means, so even the base game offers plenty of content to keep you engaged in its world and combat for hours to come. The game is also identical across PS5 and Xbox, though technical performance is a smidge smoother on Xbox, in case you happen to own both systems.

Hell is Us is a dark and dreary open-world action game that refuses to hold your hand. Compared to other similar games, there are no overwhelming map markers, excessive side quests, points of interest, and so on. Instead, the game encourages you to find your own way through its world without giving you so much as a hint. For some gamers, this may be a hindrance, but seasoned veterans of the genre may appreciate the change. Despite this, the world is much more forgiving than you'd think, and doesn't aim to make exploration too complicated, at least according to our 7/10 review by Alessandro Barbosa.

It’s relatively simple, and that’s why it’s the best New York Times game, in my opinion.

The NYT team will provide you with a grid of 16 words once a day. The only task left up to you is to sort those words into four groups of four by finding their commonalities. item.title: Call of Duty DMZ is Coming Back Soon, But There’s a Catch

It has been revealed that Call of Duty’s DMZ mode is returning in December, but there’s a huge catch. The once-popular extraction shooter platform first emerged in Modern Warfare II in 2022, but after a few months of updates, it eventually disappeared from the ecosystem, never to return – until now.

There’s a huge catch though.

DMZ: Recon Coming December 11th

DMZ: Recon is a new extraction shooter experience coming to Call of Duty: Mobile in December. It’s a reflection of the DMZ title that was released alongside Modern Warfare II in 2022, albeit a ‘shrunk-down’ version.

It will land during COD Mobile’s Season 11 update, and like the original, it’s set to feature PvPvE gameplay. Unlike the original DMZ, it’s expected that there will be no punishment or negativity surrounding PvP, as that was a sticking point for fans of the first platform. This is reflected in there being no ‘team recruitment’ mechanics, which were in the first DMZ.

Early impressions from COD Mobile leakers suggested that DMZ: Recon will be entirely first-person and will feature an in-match buy store, just like the one found in the original DMZ mode. There will be boss characters, weapons can be levelled up in flight, and loot is based on a tier system that includes extremely rare collectibles.

Players can reportedly purchase vehicles on the fly, and as it’s a smaller experience, only eight teams of three will occupy each match.

It has also been suggested that two maps will emerge at launch on December 11th: Serpent Island and Building 21. It was also claimed from those attending preview events that players arrive in the game via a wingsuit, can use killstreaks, carry three weapons, and can extract using a helicopter system, just like the first game.

“168 remaining until the end of the world…”

In a world steeped in despair and chaos, a strange religious organization called Shuten Order emerges, yearning for the end of humanity. The group rapidly gains followers, eventually forming a small nation state called Shuten.

Tragedy strikes during the grand festival celebrating their nation’s founding—the leader of the Shuten Order is murdered. To survive, the protagonist must overcome “God’s trial”: identify and kill their murderer.

With the clock ticking, the protagonist, given the alias Rei, dives into the tumultuous city as a detective. The suspects? Five ministers of the Shuten Order. There’s no time to investigate them all. Choices must be made, and the pursuit of truth demands sacrifice.

Who killed the Founder? For what reason? Can the mission be fulfilled before time runs out?

  • Ministry of Education: Romance Adventure (?!)

    • A romance adventure-style game where the goal is to build deep connections with three heroines.

item.title: Govee Dumps Color Floor Lamps, Now Selling at New All-Time Low for Prime Members
item.content:encoded:
Smart lighting transforms bland rooms into dynamic spaces that adapt to mood and activity. Govee just dropped an exclusive Prime member deal on its RGBIC Floor Lamp, slashing the price down to $64 from its usual $99. This Black Friday discount is a record low that no one other than a Prime member gets, and if you subscribe, now’s the perfect time to upgrade your lighting game. With 16 million color options and music sync capabilities, the lamp does away with dead corners and bland ambient lighting.

See at Amazon

The RGBIC designation means this lamp displays multiple colors simultaneously across different segments. Traditional RGB lamps can only show one color at a time across the entire fixture, limiting your creative options. The Govee lamp divides the light strip into independent zones that each display different colors, creating flowing gradients and multi-color effects. You can set the bottom to glow blue while the top fades into purple or create rainbow effects that flow up and down the lamp.

The 1000 lumen output provides serious brightness that actually works as primary lighting, not accent mood lighting. You can light up an entire corner of a room or use it as your main light source when you want softer, interesting lighting than overhead fixtures provide. The brightness smoothly adjusts from dim ambient glow to full brightness, allowing for granular control over the light intensity.

Syncs With Music

Music sync capability turns the lamp into a reactive light show, pulsing and changing with whatever you’re playing. Equipped with a built-in microphone, the lamp picks up the audio from your room and analyzes the beat, tempo, and intensity. Colors shift and pulse in rhythm to your music, creating an immersive experience that beats static lighting. Sensitivity can be changed depending on volumes of playing music, so it will be as relevant for background jazz as for electronic dance music played at full volume. The sync works with any audio source in the room, from TV shows to Spotify to live instruments.

Alexa integration means that when it’s all connected to your Amazon Echo devices, the lamp is completely voice-controllable. Without needing to open the app or touch physical controls, saying, “Alexa, turn on the floor lamp” powers it up. You can change colors with your voice, adjust brightness, turn the lamp on or off, and trigger preset scenes. This voice control becomes key when you are caught up on the couch and do not want to reach for your phone.

The Govee app unlocks the full potential of the lamp’s 16 million color options. You can save custom color combinations as presets, browse community-created scenes, and fine-tune every aspect of the lighting. The app includes dozens of pre-programmed scenes like “Sunset,” “Ocean,” “Forest,” and “Party” that change the lamp’s appearance with one tap. DIY mode lets you pick specific colors for each segment of the lamp, creating personalized combinations that match your room’s color scheme.

From unboxing to first use, the lamp takes about five minutes to set up. Plug in the lamp, download the Govee app, connect it to your WiFi network, and go. The WiFi connection is a standard 2.4GHz network which most homes are already set up with-no special router configurations are required. The lamp remembers your last settings even in the event of power outages, so it will immediately go back to those settings upon being turned back on. Energy consumption stays very low despite the brightness of the output; it uses about as much electricity as a regular LED bulb while offering much more functionality.

This Govee RGBIC Floor Lamp provides smart lighting features that other brands sell at double the price, down to $64 from its usual $99, for Prime members only.

item.title: Riftbound Origins Review - A TCG With Movement Strategy, I'm in!
item.content:encoded:
I got a chance to get my hands on Riftbound earlier this year as I was invited to Riot HQ to test out some trial decks. I've dabbled in a lot of TCGs over the years, finding elements that I like and dislike about them, but I've never enjoyed one quite as much as Riftbound off the bat. As I dive into the Proving Grounds beginner set, the starter decks and deckbuilding, and playing the game I'll get into what makes this game such a strong contender.

Your Cards Teach You Deckbuilding

In talking about Riftbound and how to play the game we've got to talk about how the decks are made. Each Deck has a Legend, a two colored card that features a League of Legends Champion that will serve as the face of your deck. From there, you'll then also want a Champion Unit, normally the same League of Legends hero as another ambassador for your deck.

Your Legend will have an ability that can be accessed at any time, normally once a turn, while your Champion Unit is a Unit you can summon with the required Runes without having to worry about drawing it to your hand.

In picking these two cards you've immediately been able to narrow down your pool of possible cards to two colors, and even further you'll look to obtain cards that interact positively with the abilities of your Legend and Champion Unit.

Hand of Noxus, Darius' Legend card, gives you an additional Rune as a Legion ability, while Lee Sin's Blind Monk, can buff a friendly unit. From here you can find all manner of other cards that will have Legion effects or allow for the spending of buffs.

It's in this way that as you create your deck based off the chosed Legend you're being taught by the game "This is how a deck using these cards will want to function, so you should continue to work with that mechanic." While loose, it's a basic framework that means even if you don't know all of the cards or the best strategies that you can start planning your own combos.

The rest of your deck gets filled with 39 additional cards; Units, Spells, and Gear. Each deck will also include three different Battlefields, potential battle grounds that you'll be moving your units to and from during games of Riftbound, and 12 Rune cards (six of each color) that work as your ramping energy system for the game.

Interestingly, the cards that I was most short on opening booster packs was Runes. Each pack has 1, maybe 2, that to create a deck with 12 of the same colored Runes you'll need to hope that you open enough of a certain type. For a lot of my playtesting, I just pooled all of my Runes from Boosters, Proving Grounds, and Starter Decks together so that I'd have enough. There will definitely be a time where I don't need to do that… but that time is not now.

Proving Grounds Is Where To Start

If you're just interested in getting into Riftbound, Riot Games has created a box for up to four players. This is something a bit closer to a board game approach to Riftbound but works as a starter set with underpowered decks to hopefully keep scalpers away.

Inside this box you'll find a large set of rules for how to play Riftbound, four Riftbound Decks, four Carboard Play Mats with additional instructions for how to play on them, oversized battleground cards, and acrylic character standees to use as point trackers.

While this box was planned to be less desirable, it hasn't stopped a few cards, such as the Flash spell and the Master Yi and Annie Legends, from becoming very desirable.

Playing Riftbound

Riftbound can be played with two to four players in pretty much any configuration from 1v1, to 2v2, and free for all. On each turn a player channels (draws) an additional two Runes, draws a card from their deck, and then can take any number of actions provided they're allowed to and they have the Runes to back it up.

Before the game is started Battlefields are put out on the table, these are zones that combat will take place in. Each player has a chance to contribute their own Battlefield as a way to potentially give themselves an additional advantage. Playing with friends, I never seemed to get to use my Battlefield and when a friend had a Battlefield that made use of Buffs (something my deck had none of) there was immediately an uphill battle to be had.

Players will summon Units to their field, activate Gear and Abilities, cast spells, or move their units from their base to a battlefield, resolve combat where necessary and pass their turn to the next player.

There are a lot of common aspects that you'll find in Riftbound if you're familiar with other TCGs: Units come out exhausted unless they have an ability to say otherwise, Runes create an energy that's accumulated to play cards etc.

The two major differences for Riftbound that I have really enjoyed are its Battlefields and the ramping Rune system.

When summoning a Unit you can normally only summon them to your base, which is a zone that's (normally) safe from your enemies. It's only when you start moving them out to the previously mentioned battlefields that they are at risk. Battlefields are where you earn points, so it's important to get Units out there, but the base lets you be more deliberate about when you do and don't want to engage in combat.

Playing in a free for all, being high on points but low on Units, I was able to look at my board and hand and know that I didn't have anything to make any power plays this turn but I was able to take two turns to focus on my base, filling it up with Units and abilities to then launch an assault later. When to move your characters up, and when to lie in wait, becomes a bit of a game of chicken waiting for the right time to strike.

The other feature that I really love from Riftbound is that your Runes are constantly accumulating. Each turn there's two more energy to be able to spend on more units of weaker strength, or you can gain access to far stronger units. This ramping guarantees there's no way you're stuck with nothing to do at any point in time, and better than that it always means there's escalation to the tempo of the game.

Round 1 and 2 are always one or two cards being played, and then passing on, while round 8 or 9 has you chaining together a variety of different abilities letting your Legend abilities truly shine.

There's an excitement that's inherent to pretty much every Riftbound game I have played as you get to see your opponent building up their abilities and you try to stop them.

Riftbound Facing Standard TCG Issues

As expected, Riftbound is facing current issues of pretty much every TCG, high resale and scalpers. It's not really something that can be avoided, and I definitely didn't think that Riot would have an answer, but it does make me worry about my own ability to enjoy the game outside of digital simulators.

As we go into Set 2: Spiritforged, already set to release in February of 2026, it will be interesting to see how the general public is able to get their hands on the product.

I do hope that we'll eventually see an official simulator, but for now I'm going to continue enjoying my time with the three decks that I was able to make from a Booster Box.

Riftbound Review | Final Thoughts

I'm a huge fan of Riftbound, everything that I enjoyed about playing it earlier this year is even better now that I'm able to be playing it with a wider variety of players and have more cards to craft decks out of.

I love how intuitive building a basic deck is, and how playing and refining it helps you continue to funnel towards what might be your 'perfect' deck. In addition to that I love how varied each of the different major abilities in the game are. Even when playing your own deck a number of times the way you need to respond to a trap player vs a ganking player is going to cause you to reconsider strategies at any point in the game.

I think what Riot Games has pulled off here is incredible, creating a fresh and quite unique TCG in what is a very busy space right now and it's almost terrifying to think with how many LoL champions out there how much room they have to continue growing.

Riftbound Origins was reviewed with a copy provided by the Publisher over the course of 20 hours of gameplay - all screenshots were taken during the process of review.

item.title: LEGO Goes Big on Harry Potter With Major Deal, Hogwarts Castle Set Now Costs Pocket Change
item.content:encoded:
LEGO display sets represent a creative outlet for adults that melds nostalgia with serious building satisfaction. Amazon is flooded with LEGO deals this Black Friday, but the Hogwarts Castle and Grounds set stands well above the crowd as the most iconic Harry Potter build on offer. This 2,660-piece masterpiece drops to $140 from its usual $169 price, making it the perfect time to grab what many collectors consider the definitive Hogwarts model in existence. Due to its massive scale and incredible detail, this set costs well more than average LEGO builds even at full price, but this discount makes it more affordable.

See at Amazon

The Most Intricate Hogwarts Creation LEGO has Ever Built

Detail is captured with this scale model of Hogwarts Castle in ways that no LEGO attempts have ever quite achieved: the build of the Main Tower, Astronomy Tower, Great Hall, several courtyards and connecting bridges, functional greenhouses, Boathouse, and even the surrounding Black Lake at the castle grounds. Architecture faithfully adheres to the movie depictions, giving you a displayable replica any Harry Potter fan can easily recognize. The baseplate is 13.5 inches wide and 10 inches deep, and creates a large footprint that commands attention on any shelf or desk. The castle itself rises over 8.5 inches high which makes it a fantastic centerpiece that won’t require a microscope to appreciate.

The interior details reveal the hidden rooms and iconic locations that defined the Harry Potter series. You can build the Chamber of Secrets complete with the basilisk’s lair, the Winged Key room from the first film, Snape’s Potions Classroom in the dungeons, and the life-sized Chessboard Chamber. These interior spaces add much depth to what might have been just an exterior shell, giving reasons for investigating the model from all angles.

The grounds around it feature components that complete the Hogwarts experience rather than a mere castle structure. The Durmstrang Ship sits in the Black Lake, recreating one of the dramatic entrances featured in Goblet of Fire. The Beauxbatons Carriage sits ready near the castle gates, recreating an entrance to the Triwizard Tournament. The Whomping Willow stands with its characteristic twisted branches, and the crashed Ford Anglia rests nearby as a nod to Chamber of Secrets.

The 2,660-piece count gives you hours of engaging building which breaks down into sections. LEGO designed the instructions to guide you through one area at a time, preventing the overwhelming feeling that massive sets sometimes create. You can build the castle over several evenings and make it a relaxing activity rather than a marathon building session. The variety of bricks includes special pieces for architectural details, transparent pieces for windows, and textured pieces adding depth aesthetically to walls and roofs.

Adding a really premium feel to the display is the inclusion of the gold-colored mini-figure of the statue of the Hogwarts architect. item.title: Fangtopia is a scarily delightful puzzle city-builder that I could probably sink my fangs into for a few hours
item.content:encoded:
It certainly won't send shivers down your spine

A bit of creepy crawly, low-key city building? Ah, go on then. October and Halloween might be behind us, but Fangtopia is a puzzle game stroke city builder that still feels appropriate for late autumn. Having had a go with its demo, it's deceptively simple, in fact it felt so simple I wasn't entirely sure if I was doing anything at all. But when it clicked, all the pieces fell into place resulting in a pleasantly chill time.

The game is tile based, each tile having six sides, all of which are rotatable. These tiles come in different flavours, like forest tile, or a mountain tile, a wheat field tile, a village tile etc., you get it! And then some of these tiles mix and match those traits, hence why they're rotatable. You only have a certain amount of these tiles in what is essentially a deck of cards, though I hesitate to call it a deck builder, it's more just that each tile you're able to place is random from one move to the next. Placing certain amounts of tiles next to particular landmarks that crop up then add more tiles back into your deck, so you can keep building your little island.

Once you build up your little island, classic monsters like werewolves, yetis and the like crop up and they do their own thing. You know, monster stuff. One of my favourite aspects was that you could build your own little spectral trainline too. It was mostly for the aesthetics, though (I think) also helps you gather tile resources, but really I was just in it for watching the ghost train navigate its way along the path I set for it.

It reminded me of Lego Loco, an old simulation game where you build up a town and train network for minifigures that my dad would leave me to play obsessively at his work to keep me distracted. There's something so delightful in building up a quiet corner of the world with not particularly high stakes, a quality I think comes through quite nicely in Fangtopia. Worth a punt, whenever it comes out! You can wishlist it on Steam and try out its demo in the meantime.

item.title: Apple Dumps 13-Inch iPad Pro M4 at New Record Low, Now More Tempting Than Pricey M5 Models
item.content:encoded:
Premium tablets bridge the gap between laptops and phones and give you serious computing power in a portable package. Apple just unveiled its new iPad Pro M5 lineup a few weeks ago with the 13-inch model launching at $1,299, which makes the M4 version suddenly look like a steal. Amazon dropped the 13-inch iPad Pro M4 to $1,049 from its original $1,299 price and matches what you’d pay for a smaller, less capable tablet. The M4 and M5 models share so many similarities that spending $250 more for the newer chip makes zero sense for most people.

Powerful Tablet

The M4 chip inside this iPad Pro brings desktop-grade performance that makes the upgrade to M5 seem superfluous for real-world work. What’s more, the 10-core CPU tackles tasks like video editing, 3D rendering, music production and multitasking without breaking a sweat. Apple built the M4 on a 3nm process that balances raw power with incredible efficiency, giving you all-day battery life even under intensive tasks. A 10-core GPU further pushes graphics performance to levels comparable to serious gaming machines, making this tablet ideal both for creative work and entertainment. The difference between M4 and M5 mainly exists in benchmark scores which most people never notice in real use.

The Ultra Retina XDR display represents one of the best screens ever put on a tablet. This 13-inch panel gives truly extreme brightness that remains readable in direct sunlight, while also offering deep blacks to make the OLED screens jealous. ProMotion technology adjusts the refresh rate to up to 120Hz for smooth scrolling and responsive input from Apple Pencil, then drops right down to conserve battery when the on-screen content has become static. P3 wide color gamut reproduces colors more accurately than standard displays, something that makes a big difference with photo editing and creative work. True Tone adjusts color temperature according to ambient lighting to reduce eye strain with extended use.

The impossibly thin design makes this 13-inch tablet feel lighter than its size suggests: Apple shaved the thickness down to just 5.1mm and created a profile that slips into bags easily with no extra bulk. A Space Black finish does a better job of resisting fingerprints than past aluminum finishes on Apple’s tablets, so the device stays clean throughout the day. The weight reduction means that you can hold the iPad Pro comfortably through marathon reading sessions or video calls without your arm tiring. The overall structural rigidity is impressive for such a slim frame, and the tablet doesn’t flex or creak at all if you press hard.

Apple Intelligence integration changes how you’ll interact with the iPad Pro using AI-infused features: It helps write emails, summarize information, create images, and organize material all through natural language. It also includes privacy protections that mean all of this AI processing happens locally on your device rather than by sending sensitive information to cloud servers. The AI features seamlessly connect apps by suggesting what should be done next based on context, and the more you use them, the better they learn your preferences.

The new landscape 12MP Ultra Wide front camera finally puts the camera where it belongs for video calls. Center Stage automatically keeps you in frame as you move around, making video conferences feel more natural and professional. The 12MP Wide back camera captures stunning photos and 4K video with ProRes support for professional editing workflows. Four studio-quality microphones record clear audio from any direction while the four-speaker system delivers rich, immersive sound.

This iPad Pro M4 provides flagship performance for $250 less than the nearly identical M5 model down from $1,299 to $1,049. For your money, you’re getting the same Ultra Retina XDR display, similar processing power, an identical design, and full Apple Intelligence support, making the upgrade to an M5 unit a pretty questionable decision. The fact that this Amazon-exclusive discount combines with those cutting-edge specs to create value that’s out of reach for Apple’s official store is rather fascinating.
